name: Ghostndragon
comment info: Some plants and crops really do need the winter to survive/thrive. For example, some need a cold period for seeds to germinate (and some need to have extreme heat, such as a wildfire to germinate). Some need cool weather to do well after the last frost. Some can't deal with high humidity that comes with warmer weather, and will get fungal infections. And some need the cold to kill insect pests to keep from being eaten up over the growing season due to too many insects. Never mind that some beneficial animals and insects need the cold to also survive/thrive (warming climates may help mites on bees survive, creating problems for native bees, as well as honey bees). As a result, the shifting climate will almost certainly make it difficult, if not impossible to grow certain plants, and maybe even cause the extinction of some plants/crops/insects. For example, wild rice and oats do best in cooler climates, both of which are very nutritious, and wild rice is native to North America and an important crop for some Indigenous tribes.

So that part was interesting to me.
	While this graph does not directly impact my community, I can draw some conclusions. Temperatures are increasing dramatically, even in places so close to the Arctic, and that can influence plant growing rates. Places which were 20 degrees (Celsius) might rise to 25 degrees, and places which were 25 degrees might rise to 30 degrees. So, what does this mean? Many areas, especially on the border, as they are closer to the equator, will become more arid and make for harder plant growth. comment info:
I notice that the warmer temperatures are mostly in southern & southwestern states from Florida up to California. However, as we move towards the center of the U.S. our temperature becomes dramatically colder. If we compare these two maps we can see that map #1 has a large area that has very low temperatures. In map #2 we see that this cold area is getting smaller, northern states are slowly getting warmer.
 
I wonder if these more central states are much colder because they are not near an ocean to help regulate/distribute their temperature better. This may account for the massive crop fields up north when we don’t see farms at that scale in southern states.
 
Florida’s hot and humid climate makes it ideal for growing many crops. These include citrus, sugarcane, tomatoes, peppers, cotton, and many more. Our most well-known agricultural product is oranges. If we look at how Florida changes in these maps, Florida is actually getting warmer. Map #1 shows most of Florida is around 30 - 40 degrees. However, in map #2 just over half of the state is in the red. This means that Florida got warmer during this period.
 
This graph is showing us the hardiness zones. These 10 zones represent a temperature variation of 10 degrees ranging from 40 degrees to -40 degrees Fahrenheit. This ultimately shows where farmers are more likely to grow crops, and where might produce a large yield.

name: Eva G. Martinez
comment info:
The first thing I notice is the shrinking area of zone three. This area represents colder temperatures, which may have a drastic impact on evergreen forests and their ecosystems. The second thing I notice is the increase of places within zone 10; although the general area of each zone can be expected to fluctuate due to dynamic equilibrium or general climatology, the rapid influx of high heat areas does not appear to change. Third I also notice the impact these changing zones have on America's great plains. The plains make up a large portion of the American farming sector and are essential to the economy. As the temperature changes, so does the precipitation rate, which may bring about changes to soil composition. If climate change continues, land may not just be too hot but too dry or lack nutrients to farm with.   

While some commentators may argue that this is an issue that will have minimal impact on them directly, irrespective of the fact that climate change is a global issue, the potential economic implications of a situation like this can send the American economy spiraling downwards. Farming is a billion-dollar industry that feeds into the shipping and food sales market. These industries have employees, land, etc.; without them, Americans lose jobs and industry. Companies and individuals like to flout proposed climate regulations, but this is a short-sided viewpoint that may spell out tragedy for modern America. 

Headline: The Things We Lost in the Fire

name: Brooke, Elle, Rose, Sarah
comment info:
"How Has Global Warming Affected Growing Zones?"

After examining the graph, our group noticed a number of things such as the zone 3 part of the graph will become nearly eliminated on the 2011-2040 graph. We also noticed that zone 6-10 will take over almost the whole graph in 2011-2040. The West Coast’s growing zones do not change as dramatically as the rest of the growing zones. Also, the zones are relatively evenly distributed in the 1981-2010 graph but in the 2011-2040 graph they become uneven and unpredictable. We wondered some things after looking at the graph, like how this is affecting the crops that grow in the changing areas? Will the crops that grow there now be different in the future? How does this affect the prices of food? We also wondered how this will impact the United States’ food supply and which crops will not be able to be produced in the US in the 2011-2040 graph that were produced in 1981-2010. This graph impacts us and our community as we live in Minnesota, which is in zone 5 of the growing season in the 2011-2040 graph. The average winter lows for this zone are -20 to -10. This tells us that the rise in temperatures when we reach summer can affect plant growth and the economy. Minnesota plays a big role in the agriculture community and the weather is very important in order for the plants to grow.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Brooke, Elle, Rose, Sarah --

You have two very interesting noticings:  “the West Coast’s growing zones do not change as dramatically” and “in the 2011-2040 graph they become uneven and unpredictable.”  Do you have hypotheses about why these changes are in the projected plant hardiness zone maps?

With much of Minnesota going from Zone 4 to Zone 5, the ice fishing season is going to be shorter and the lake ice out dates are going to be earlier.

name: Grace U, Kaitlin B, Evan D, Brian S
comment info: Based on these graphs, our group noticed that overall temperatures seem to get warmer. The warmer colors are moving up from the South. The climate on the West coast has largely stayed the same throughout the last few decades. We wonder what is causing the shift to a warmer climate? How long has this trend towards a warmer climate been going for? Is this a natural occurrence throughout the last few centuries or is this a recent trend that is man made? We also wonder why the Pacific Northwest is far warmer than other northern areas? Lastly, what are these projections being based on? This shift towards a warmer climate can have major implications for our community. A possibility of rising sea levels and larger agricultural factors can potentially displace many people and affect the economy. With a rising temperature, it is important to understand what crops can still be planted throughout the year. We would headline this article, “Danger, climate crisis ahead!”

replies.comment info:
HI, @Grace U, Kaitlin B, Evan D, Brian S --

Interesting wonders about why the Pacific Northwest is different and whether this change was been underway for centuries.

Do you have any other insights based on the fact that grow zones are based on “the coldest temperature of the year at each location averaged over a 30-year period?”  This says nothing about hottest temperatures or precipitation.
replies.reply to: Grace U, Kaitlin B, Evan D, Brian S

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s choropleths (maps with data represented by gradations of color) show the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) growing zones for three time periods:  historical 1971-2000 and 1981-2010 and projected 2011-2040.  How have growing zones and, therefore, climate changed?  What effect does this have on plants and on us?

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you and your community?”

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these maps. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included these maps and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

Keep noticing and wondering.  The next graph on life expectancy will be released by Friday, April 9 with moderation on Wednesday, April 14.

name: Aeryn
comment info:
One big thing I notice is the hardiness zones in the projected graph become higher in temperature and move north. There is more deeper red (Zone 10) in the projected graph in the southern portion than the historical graph. Zone 3 is nearly pushed out of the north by zone 4. A lot of the pockets of the lower zones also disappear in the projected graph (like in the northwestern states and the northeast).
I wonder how this change in zones will affect American agriculture. The zones that hold a lot of agriculture (the midwest and south) seem to continue to increase greatly in temperature. Will this affect agricultural output and the health of crops, as well as soil health? I know the graph shows winter hardiness but a lot of farms continue through the winter for year-round production, and this trend likely continues into the spring and summer.
The area I live in, the PNW, seems to be going into the highest hardiness zones. I know a lot of people have home gardens that continue through the winter and I'd be interested to know how this will affect them as well. I also know a lot of people that enjoy winter sports in the mountains of the PNW, so will this temperature change also change the snowfall we see at higher elevations?
